3.2 grams of size 11/0 Miyuki round seed beads in white-lined brown, 11-0756D (C)

Christmas 2009: Gift ideas for teen girls under $10

Christmas and holiday shopping for teens can be stressful. You want to get them something they will enjoy yet you don't want to break the bank. Teens have their own language, their own set of rules and while they hate to admit it, most want to follow the pack and have the trendy and cool items everyone else has. What do you do if you have a small budget but still want to get something nice that is in style, trendy and useful? Well, if you are buying for a teen girl this holiday season, relax, there are several choices you can buy that are $10.00 or under that she will love.

First thing first, know whom you are buying for, what they like and what things they are into. If you are buying for a girl who is into fashion and not sporty, getting her gym shorts wouldn't mean much. On the other hand, if you're buying for a girl who is captain of her soccer team and not into fashion, getting her the latest trend of earrings won't mean much. With this in mind, check out the list below for some great ideas and the type of girl who the gift would go well with. 1. Shoe organizer for under the bed, $9.99 at Target. This is a good gift for anyone and what teen girl these days doesn't have a ton of shoes, whether she is a fashionista or a sports freak. 2. Manicure and Pedicure gift set, under $10.00 at most drug stores. This is good for the girl that likes to keep her toes and fingers in tip top shape. Many kits are less then $10.00 but you can also put one together on your own. Get a small basket from the dollar store and fill it with nail files, clippers, cuticle cream and one or two nail polishes. 3. Gift cards. Gift cards are great and most come in any denomination. Most teens these days have iPods so an iTunes card is perfect. You can also get gift cards from restaurants they love or mall cards good for most stores at a mall they like shopping at. 4. Costume Jewelry. This is more for the girl that is into fashion but don't count the sporty girl out yet. There are a lot of the leather bracelets that are popular and all the girls love them. For the costume jewelry, there are tons of choices for earrings, necklaces and bracelets that are well under $10.00. Clairs and Icing are two chains that have a wide selection. 5. Hair and Skin Products. This fits every type of girl and during the holiday season you should find products packaged and sold together as gifts. Shampoos, conditioners and hair gels are all great choices and many come in travel sizes, great for sleepovers, that are under $10.00. Don't forget moisturizers, cleansers and cotton pads since most girls this age start to really take an interest in their skin care. 6. Magazine subscriptions. You can pick on that holds an interest for the girl you are buying for, a sporting magazine, fashion one or even one of the teen gossip ones are great gifts and every month they have something to look forward to. Many are less then $10.00 for a year's subscription. 7. Movies, music and books. Every teenager loves music and movies but don't forget about books. Maybe one the newest tittles in a series they are hooked on? Being creative in the presentation of the gift adds flair and is exciting to open. Make gift baskets that are pretty and add candy, gum and mints as fillers. Make your own gift bag using plain color bags from the dollar store. Use a program online for pictures of the girl with captions that apply to her and paste them on the bag with ribbons. Having a small amount of money doesn't mean the gift won't be something special. If you are careful about buying items that will be used and presented in a special way, your gift will be appreciated and enjoyed.

Style guides for mums

Who wants to be a stylish mom? Who wants other moms to envy? Well I do! I've got the experience and know how to look good and cute, while not spending a fortune. Who has the money to dress like Cindy Crawford or Jennifer Lopez - well I don't! I can give you the basics to start off dressing smartly and economically.First item: A great pair of jeans sets off the entire look. Spend the extra money to purchase a pair of great jeans, they will last you years and keep their shape and color. If you are thin and have the figure, purchase couple of pairs at high end boutiques or department stores. If you are full-figure and not model shaped, check out on-line stores such as Gap, Nordstrom's or Dillard's.

Shoes: Invest in a pair of cute sneakers in a couple of colors; dark for winter, light for summer. One pair of boots, sandals and flip flops are the basics for busy moms. If you can pull it off, wear some fashionable heels with those jeans! Spend some good money on your shoes, they will last you for years.T-Shirts: I live in my T's and I spend a lot of time buying hip T's with slogans and designs and trying to locate the best price. Check out on-line retailers, they usually offer the best deals that you will not find at their stores. Shirts don't last long, so don't spend over $100 for a tee..if you're a mom, you will get it stained.Purse and Accessories: Buy one great purse that you can pack the kids stuff in and will also look nice if you go out with your hubby. Stay away from all plastic and steer towards partial or all leather products, it will last you much longer. You can buy lots of costume jewelry to dress up your outfits, check out sales - they are always going on for these types of items. Think about making your own - release your creative spirit.Lastly - A great haircut!: Keep this simple and don't overdo it. I've seen housewives with these huge styles and I have to laugh. Fancy hair, lots of make-up and tennies, while out with the kids; it doesn't work so don't do it.Remember, keep your clothes clean and mix it up with your regular low-end clothes. The other housewives will think you are spending a fortune on your clothes..make them envy. This has always worked for me and I do get complimented on my style. Little do they know that I am wearing a $5 T-Shirt, $60 jeans and $40 shoes, $12 purse and costume jewelry I made myself. Research on-line stores, you will find bargains. Good luck ladies!
http://www.tiffanymylove.com

Bridesmaids dresses and choosing the right ones

Your bridesmaid is having cold stilettos? Fear of being bedecked in floral fiascoes, prom-picture throwbacks, or unflattering frocks is enough to make any girl give her place in the wedding-party line second thoughts - no matter how much she loves the bride-to-be.
But it is possible to pick dresses that complement every body shape and personality - without destroying your wedding color palette, much less your friendships. The key: Give them a choice. Here's a rundown of how to score bridesmaids dresses they'll love, according to three bride personalities.

~ Traditional: Go chic, go cheap
A common myth spawned by bridezilla: "You can just hem it and make it into a fun summer dress that you can wear forever and ever!" Dream on.
But if there's one thing that might trump fashion, it's frugality. And the bridal market is such big business that finding a variety of dresses that complement your wedding colors - and for rock-bottom prices - makes it easier to keep everybody happy (or at least accepting). Pay for the dresses yourself, and you'll ensure even more willing torsos.
Large chain stores follow fashion trends and offer an ever-changing array of dress styles, including mix-and-match separates, that leave any bridesmaid hard-pressed not to find at least one dress she likes. National locations also let out-of-town bridesmaids see what's available, try styles on, and get fitted.
~ Flexible: Focus on accessories
One of the simplest ways to give bridesmaids a say in what they wear, while maintaining a theme, is to put the spotlight on the little things they will share, such as flowers, jewelry, or scarves. Ask bridesmaids to provide their own dresses in a neutral color. Who doesn't have a little black dress in their closet? (Heck, if they don't, you're doing them a fashion favor by requesting they purchase one.) Then provide them with matching accessories that highlight your wedding palette, perhaps as your gift for being in the wedding party.
Worried that black is a bit drab for a summer affair? Don't worry; that fashion faux paus went out the door with the old rule of "no white after Labor Day." But to stay in season, request a knee- or tea-length dress.
Some novel accessory ideas to spice things up: chic clutch purses instead of bouquets that they can use for the after-party; cropped jackets instead of shawls that can be ditched before the dance floor; or fresh flowers tucked into up-do's that match the bridal bouquet.
~ Free Spirit: Free for all fun
Is there some kind of Wedding Bible that says "Thou shalt require matching gowns with puffy sleeves in fuchsia"? Please. Today's brides are just as likely to walk themselves down the aisle, have a Man of Honor stand by their side, and forgo the chapel for a national park. So here's the permission you need: Go ahead and break the rules!
Some fun alternatives: pick a historical era and then go on a group shopping spree with your bridesmaids (or bridesmen) to vintage clothing shops to find lace gloves, parasols, flapper dresses, or old-style hats; dig into closets to pull out those old prom dresses or suits; or have them wear simple sun dresses and buy matching sunglasses.
Is it "all about the bride"? You bet. But these approaches can help make sure her best buds have some fun while they make sure of it.
[url=][/url]

How to look hot when its cold

You may normally look hot with a revealing outfit, however in the coolness of winter's breath, such outfits are not suitable. There are many ways that you can still look hot when it is cold, however. Wear flattering jeans There is something very sexy about a pair of tight jeans. Women with or without curves can often look their best in a pair of hip hugging jeans, which are warm enough to work for the outside but hot enough to give you your personal taste. You will find many different styles, some with fun embellishments such as crystals and embroidery. You can also look for stretchy jeans if you want something a little more comfortable. Add a fun wide belt for an added touch.

Wear tight shirts Just because you need to cover everything does not mean that it cannot show off your curves. There are many attractive shirts that can show off what you got. If it is not too cold, you can also let a little cleavage peek through for an attractive look. Even a turtleneck can be very sexy, however. Wear sexy boots There are many sexy boots that can make you appear taller, leaner and just more sexy. You will find knee high black velvet boots, for instance. They make these boots with all different looks. A lot of them have high heels. These look great with jeans as well as with winter dresses. Wear a fashionable coat There are many fashionable coats that can make you look very hot. These can look very sophisticated. A guy can wear a cool jacket. Wear your hair in an attractive style It is not just clothing that can make you look hot. You can wear your hair in a sexy hairstyle. You can get some beautiful highlights to wear for the winter. You can get a perm or some hair extensions to give yourself a sexy look. In addition to having a nice haircut, you can style it nicely on a daily basis. Makeup Although makeup is not necessary for someone to look "hot," it can be very attractive on many women. You can wear some sultry red lipstick or a subtle but attractive mauve. Accessories Jewelry and other accessories can make one appear sexier. You can get a sexy choker or a lot of layered chains to wear. There are many ways to look hot even in the dead of winter. The above techniques may give you the look for which you are looking.
[url=][/url]

Lariat Necklaces - Jewelry Top Picks

Lariat necklaces are traditionally very long--long enough to wrap around your neck two or more times--and unattached at their ends so that you can tie and knot them in different ways to suit your style. Some necklaces have the lariat look, knotted or clustered in the front with a decorative "tassel" hanging down from the center, but secured in back with a clasp. You'll find both types in this lariat necklace collection.1’ Lori Lori Double LariatThis 14K gold filled lariat is forty-six inches long, which gives you plenty of options for wearing it. The lariat is beaded with Swarovski crystals in four color choices.Buy Direct2’ Sterling Silver Freshwater Cultured Pearl Heart Lariat NecklaceA freshwater pearl on a sterling silver snake chain drops through and below a sterling silver heart. Finding Your Jewelry Selling Direction

When first starting a jewelry business, after worrying about all the legal requirements of a small business, most jewelry makers discover that there is much more to be concerned about when it comes to marketing their hand-crafted jewelry. This is a universal problem, no matter if you make bead, wire, metal, glass, or clay jewelry. It all comes down to, okay now, how am I going to sell my jewelry art? Should I participate in art shows? Should I sell to shops? How do I begin, and what direction should I take?
David A. Weiman, Marketing Director for Lapidary Journal and Step by Step Beads magazine, offers his point of view and personal insights for jewelry makers who want to sell their jewelry and start a jewelry business in his virtual marketing seminar, ‘Introduction to Marketing and Selling Jewelry.’ Weiman, who also travels the country conducting live jewelry marketing seminars, combines his market career expertise, jewelry knowledge, and psychology degree to create a unique perspective. His audio CD discusses setting goals, business planning, market research, marketing techniques, personality factors, and pricing. (And, by the way, I found it really convenient to listen to the CD in my car while driving, much more convenient than traveling to a seminar in person.) The accompanying 18 page workbook literally allows you to work through some of the mental obstacles that running a jewelry making business can produce. We’ve often talked on the forum about having confidence in ourselves and our jewelry, and Weiman tackles these in both the workbook and CD.
Maybe you’ve been thinking about starting your own jewelry making business but have not had the confidence to do so, or maybe you have just started but aren’t clear about how to approach marketing your work. The inexperienced and self-doubters among us will find Weiman’s approach very helpful. For the more experienced jewelry business owner, the self-analysis techniques maybe what you need to further your success.
You can find out more about David Weiman’s virtual marketing seminar on his web site at marketingjewelry. The package (CD and hardcopy workbook) retails for $34.95 (plus shipping), and he offers a 30-day money back guarantee.

Creating Glamorous Jewelry with Swarovski Elements by Jean C

The Bottom LineA beautiful, inspiring book of beadwork using Swarovski crystals that has projects for both beginners and more advanced beaders. This book really offers something for everyone, and is a refreshing collection of Swarovski crystal beadwork projects.ProsProjects for both beginners and more advanced beadersClearly written and illustrated projectsFascinating background information about some of Hollywood's most famous actressesProjects combine materials for a unique lookConsBinding makes book hard to keep open while workingDescriptionPaperback bindingProjects for beginner and advanced beadweaversProjects showcase Swarovski elements - both beads and stonesPublished by Creative Publishing InternationalGuide Review - "Creating Glamorous Jewelry" by Jean Campbell: A Book ReviewCreating Glamorous Jewelry with Swarovski Elements: Classic Hollywood Designs with Crystal Beads and Stones, Jean Campbell, $24.99, Creative Publishing International
Jean Campbell, the founding editor of Beadwork Magazine, looks to old Hollywood for inspiration for her latest book, "Creating Glamorous Jewelry with Swarovski Elements: Classic Hollywood Designs with Crystal Beads and Stones".
Each of the 26 beaded jewelry projects in this book was inspired by a different Hollywood actress, including Zsa Zsa Gabor, Audrey Hepburn, Ann Sheridan, Marlene Dietrich, Dinah Shore and of course, Marilyn Monroe. Each project includes a fascinating bio of each actress that I thoroughly enjoyed. (Do you know which Hollywood actress from the 1940s was also a mathematician who helped to develop a secret communications system in World War II? Read each profile to find out!)
The projects themselves range in skill level from very easy to more advanced, and cover a wide range of techniques. There are earring, necklace and bracelet projects that include techniques like stitching beaded bezels around crystal stones, embroidery on leather, and basic stringing. Each project is carefully written and illustrated with diagrams that show thread paths and stitching techniques.
A "Basics" section at the end of the book covers basic beadweaving and stringing techniques with information about materials and findings used in the projects. Jean has also included some helpful information about stitching with thread and crystals, including specific product recommendations. Lastly, she has also included a brief and informative article about Daniel Swarovski, his revolutionary faceting machine, and his influence on haute couture in Hollywood.
If you were someone, like me, who was getting tired of seeing Swarovski crystals in every single beading project, this book will give you some fresh inspiration for using Swarovski crystals in beadwork. I love the way Jean has mixed glass crystals with crystal pearls, seed beads, chain and even gemstones to faithfully re-create the jewelry worn by these glamorous ladies from Hollywood. Jean has drawn on her technical expertise and artistic mastery to write a beadwork book that perfectly captures the best of Hollywood glamour in beads.
